The reason it seems conflicting is that the issue isn't a binary thing. It's not a video game where you wear Immune to Poison gear and you can't get sick.

The first issue is that of viral loads. You can think of it as rolling dice, both in amount and frequency. The more virus you get, the better chance you get sick. There's little you can do to totally eliminate the risk, but you can reduce the amount of 'dice' rolled, and thus reduce the chance. The easiest way to communicate this to the public is to simply say, "wear masks"

The second is how COVID is transmitted. Again, people wanted it to be like a video game: it's either transmitted via droplets or airborne. I played Plague Inc, so just tell me which tree it specced in!!!

But that's not how it works. There's a lot of overlap, as a 'droplet' can be propelled a great deal by a cough or a sneeze. Further, if a droplet is small enough it essentially can stay in the air, forming an aerosol.

This didn't confuse scientists, but it did confuse the public and trying to message them. How can we say COVID is not airborne yet many of our precautions are similar to an airborne virus? It's a bit like an autist explaining what an RPG is and then getting mad when the normie says "oh, like Zelda?"

So the science never actually changed, but the messaging and definitions. This is because of an ignorant general public and another group of people - like you - who think they're experts on a subject after reading it for a few minutes.

>>40764474
You have a fundamental misunderstanding of karma. It is not a moral principle.

The word karma comes from the Sanskrit root kri, meaning "to do" or "to act." Karma refers to action—more precisely, intentional action that leaves an imprint (called a samskara or vasana) in the subtle body or psyche. These imprints condition future experiences, perceptions, tendencies, and circumstances. So karma is better seen as a law of energy and causation, much like Newtonian action-reaction, but extended to consciousness itself.

Karma is not about "good" and "bad" in a moral sense. It is based on intention, not whether an action is labeled "nice" or "nasty" by cultural standards. Even seemingly kind acts done from attachment, pride, or manipulation can generate binding karma. Likewise, seemingly "bad" acts done in wisdom or from a place of inner clarity may not.

Karma is similar to momentum. When you act from craving, fear, or illusion, you set things in motion that pull you back into more of the same. It's not punishment—it's just cause and effect in the field of consciousness.

The tailwhip refers specifically to the last day of the post-shadow period or the first day after when Mercury turns direct.
It's when you go "ahh, all the shadow periods are over and mercury is fully direct now!" and then your main TV that you've had for 10 years dies.
In this specific case, the tailwhip will happen in August 26, though I've seen it happen the day after it's supposed to happen, ruining any relief you think you had because the retrograde things are supposed to be over.
I don't think the mercury tailwhip has been documented before this thread on the Internet, but it has been alluded to in TV series or movies when they point out the worst thing didn't even happen when Mercury was retrograde ("see, I told you, it's all a coincidence, this picrel calendar shows safe days with a white background so the calamity of August 27 2025 had nothing to do with Mercury retrograde", nah, it's the tailwhip).

>>40723521
Controlled remote viewing is where you are given a blind target. Meaning, someone else picks the target or subject, and then gives you usually just a string of random numbers/letters and tells you to record your impressions.
After the assignment you may or may not be told the results.
That's the kind of remote viewing being done by McMoneagle and others.

Without any information given beforehand, you aren't front loading information that could skew your results.

If you want to learn how to do it, just start meditating and quiet your conscious mind. You have to be open to impressions rising from your subconscious mind.
There's lots of books and vids on how to do it, but that is the essence.

If you end up a homeless crack addicted satanist a year later that's on you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>40773170
There's also part of the process where, if you get a visual (might not actual be visual) that you think is a distraction, you write it down, crumple the paper and toss it in the waste bin to mentally get rid of it.

I would say the main difference between RV and classical clairvoyance is control of the "aperture", to borrow the RV terminology.

Your third eye is like an aperture (hole) that you can open and close to varying sizes. In RV'ing, you start with it the size of a tiny pin prick to get as little information as possible, but make sure you have the correct target. Then you gradually open up the aperture to get a bigger and bigger picture.

Clairvoyance, on the other hand, you open up the aperture as much as you can and drink the information from the fire hose.

There's no one "right" way to do any of this and anyone who claims such is trying to sell you something.
